properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Avoca, Bung Bong, Burnbank, Caralulup, Glenlofty, Glenpatrick, Glenshee, Green Hill Creek, Lamplough, Lillicur, Nowhere Creek, Percydale, Riversdale, Rosyth, Warrenmang, Amherst, Amphitheatre, Crowlands, Elmhurst, Evansford, Frenchmans, Homebush, Landsborough, Lexton, Rathscar West, Talbot, Tanwood
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Amherst, Amphitheatre, Avoca, Bung Bong, Burnbank, Caralulup, Crowlands, Elmhurst, Evansford, Frenchmans, Glenlofty, Glenpatrick, Glenshee, Green Hill Creek, Homebush, Lamplough, Landsborough, Lexton, Lillicur, Nowhere Creek, Percydale, Rathscar West, Riversdale, Rosyth, Talbot, Tanwood, Warrenmang.

  • There is a bushfire between Mount Cole and Raglan that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bayindeen Rocky Road in a north-easterly direction.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 23/02/2024 10:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Avondale Heights, Braybrook, Sunshine North.
  • There is a factory fire on Bunnett Street Sunshine North.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • You may see or smell smoke. 
  • Firefighters are currently responding to this fire. 
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.   

Health information: 
  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. 
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).     
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health. For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/smoke-and-your-health   
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Lakes Entrance beach.

  • Due to a whale carcass, there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • The whale carcass is located at the east of Drew's Jetty. 
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by VFA.

The next update is expected by 29/02/2024 03:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Dadswells Bridge. 

  • The bushfire at Grampians National Park, Mt Stapylton is under control. 
  • Fire crews continue to patrol the fire area.
  • Strong winds may cause internal hot spots to flare up and generate increased smoke. 
  • There are reduced speed limits in place on the Western Highway through Dadswells Bridge.

Areas of the Grampians National Park near the Bellfield fire remain closed.  

For detailed information on which areas of the park are open or closed, visit www.parks.vic.gov.au.

Parks are closed or partially closed to ensure your safety. Remember, disobeying closure orders is an offense under the National Parks Act, with fines for non-compliance.

There is no immediate threat to the community or travellers on the Western Highway. You should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 24/02/2024 07:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health.  For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Areas of the Grampians National Park near the Bellfield fire remain closed. For detailed information on which areas of the park are open or closed, visit www.parks.vic.gov.au. properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Beaufort, Ben Nevis, Buangor East, Chute, Eurambeen, Langi Kal Kal, Main Lead, Mount Cole, Raglan, Trawalla, Waterloo, Bayindeen, Brewster, Buangor, Ercildoune, Eversley, Glenbrae, Glenlogie, Lexton, Middle Creek, Mount Cole Creek, Mount Lonarch, Warrak
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Bayindeen, Beaufort, Ben Nevis, Brewster, Buangor, Buangor East, Chute, Ercildoune, Eurambeen, Eversley, Glenbrae, Glenlogie, Langi Kal Kal, Lexton, Main Lead, Middle Creek, Mount Cole, Mount Cole Creek, Mount Lonarch, Raglan, Trawalla, Warrak, Waterloo. 
  • There is a bushfire between Mount Cole and Raglan that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bayindeen-Rocky Road in a north-easterly direction towards Avoca.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area. 
  •  You should leave  and head towards Ballarat.  
  •  Relief Centres are located at the CE Brown Reserve, 236-296 Dowling Street Wendouree (Lake Wendouree Football Ground), Alexander Oval, Waratah Avenue Ararat and Princes Park reserve 40 Park Road Maryborough.
  •  When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  •  Note: Relief centre at Community Bank Complex in Beaufort is closed.

In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.

If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 

If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.

If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 

  •  Beaufort Urgent Care centre in Havelock Street Beaufort is closed.  For any urgent medical emergencies call 000. 
  •   The Western Highway is closed, Northwest of Ballarat at the intersection of Western Highway and Sunraysia Highway and Ararat . 
  •  Skipton Road is closed between Skipton and Beaufort.
  • Beaufort Lexton Road is closed between Beaufort and Lexton.
  •  Traffic can still travel in a Southerly direction from Beaufort to Ballarat. 
  •  For further road closures check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 23/02/2024 05:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Burrumbeet, Ercildoune, Glenbrae, Addington, Brewster, Lexton, Trawalla, Waubra, Weatherboard
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Addington, Brewster, Burrumbeet, Ercildoune, Glenbrae, Lexton, Trawalla, Waubra, Weatherboard.

  • There is a bushfire at Bayindeen Rocky Road that is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bayindeen Rocky Road in a north-easterly direction.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Beaufort Urgent Care Centre, Havelock Street, Beaufort is closed.  For medical emergencies call 000.
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
  • Bushfires and power outages can affect the water supply and pressure.
  • Customers should not rely on town water as part of their fire plans. 
  • Leaving early is the safest option during a bushfire. In preparation for potential impacts from bushfire or power outages, please ensure you have an alternative water source available. 
  • Please also minimise non-essential water use to preserve supplies.
  • Set aside drinking water and remain mindful of minimising heat stress and keeping hydrated.
  • Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
The following roads are closed:

  • The Western Highway is closed Northwest of Ballarat at the intersection of Western Highway and Sunraysia to Ararat.
  • Intersection of Beaufort Lexton Road and Blackbottom Road Lexton.
  • Skipton Road south of Western highway.
  • Traffic can still travel in a Southerly direction from Beaufort to Ballarat.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 23/02/2024 10:40 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Amphitheatre, Elmhurst, Eversley, Glenlogie, Lexton, Mount Lonarch, Burnbank, Chute, Glenlofty, Glenpatrick, Mount Cole, Mount Cole Creek, Nowhere Creek
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Amphitheatre, Burnbank, Chute, Elmhurst, Eversley, Glenlofty, Glenlogie, Glenpatrick, Lexton, Mount Cole, Mount Cole Creek, Mount Lonarch, Nowhere Creek.

  • There is a bushfire located between Mount Cole and Raglan that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Bayindeen Rocky Road in a north-easterly direction.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the watch and Act issued at 2:03.
  • Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay. 

  • If you are not prepared, you should leave now. 

  • By choosing to stay, you and your family may be at risk of serious injury or death.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing.
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.

If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  •  Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires.  
  •  Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area. 
  •  If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see. 
  •  Defending a house requires: At least two fit and determined adults who are physically and mentally prepared to work long and hard in arduous and difficult conditions. At least 10,000 litres of water (not from mains supply which can fail during a fire). Protective clothing. Appropriate firefighting hoses and pumps.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Beaufort Urgent Care centre in Havelock Street Beaufort is closed.  For any urgent medical emergencies call 000. 
  • Community Relief Centres Relief Centres are located at the CE Brown Reserve, 236-296 Dowling Street Wendouree (Lake Wendouree Football Ground), Alexander Oval, Waratah Avenue Ararat and Princes Park reserve 40 Park Road Maryborough.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Bushfires and power outages can affect the water supply and pressure.   
  • Customers should not rely on town water as part of their fire plans. Leaving early is the safest option during a bushfire.   
  • In preparation for potential impacts from bushfire or power outages, please ensure you have an alternative water source available.  
  • Please also minimise non-essential water use to preserve supplies.  
  • Set aside drinking water and remain mindful of minimising heat stress and keeping hydrated.

The following roads are closed:  

  • Western Highway, northwest of Ballarat at the intersection of the Western Highway and Sunraysia Highway to Ararat.  
  • Intersection of Beaufort Lexton Road and Blackbottom Road, Lexton. 
  • Traffic can still travel in south from Beaufort to Ballarat.  
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 23/02/2024 06:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Italian Gully, Ross Creek, Smythesdale, Enfield, Napoleons, Newtown, Scarsdale, Staffordshire Reef
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Enfield, Italian Gully, Napoleons, Newtown, Ross Creek, Scarsdale, Smythesdale, Staffordshire Reef. 

  • This Community Information message replaces the Advice message issued at 9.21am Friday 16 February.
  • The fire that started in Newtown and spread into the Ross Creek State Forest is now under control. 
  • There is no immediate threat to the community however smoke and fire activity may still be visible in the area. 
  • Firefighters will continue to attend to the fire. Heavy vehicles may also be seen operating in the area.
  • Ross Creek State Forest tracks in and around the fire area are closed to ensure firefighter and public safety. 
Fire fighting activities are still occuring. Do not enter closed roads.

Burnt areas are dangerous. Hazardous trees can fall at any time causing serious injury or death. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 23/02/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/03/2024 05:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Tuesday 23 January 2024, 03:14 pm
Next Update: Sunday 31 March 2024, 05:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32563/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Pomonal.

  • The bushfire at Grampians National Park, Bellfield is contained. 
  • Fire crews remain in the area monitoring conditions and treating fire damaged trees. For your safety, stay away. 
  • Strong winds may cause internal hot spots to flare up and generate increased smoke. 
  • Fire affected trees can be dangerous. You should stay clear of them. 

Areas of Grampians National Park near the Bellfield fire remain closed. 

For detailed information on which areas of the park are open or closed, visit www.parks.vic.gov.au.

Parks are closed or partially closed to ensure your safety. Remember, disobeying closure orders is an offense under the National Parks Act, with fines for non-compliance. 
There is currently no fire threatening communities, however, you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Access is restricted to local residents, emergency services and essential services. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au/) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 24/02/2024 07:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

For your safety, stay away. - Strong winds may cause internal hot spots to flare up and generate increased smoke. - Fire affected trees can be dangerous. You should stay clear of them. Areas of Grampians National Park near the Bellfield fire remain closed. For detailed information on which areas of the park are open or closed, visit www.parks.vic.gov.au. Parks are closed or partially closed to ensure your safety. Remember, disobeying closure orders is an offense under the National Parks Act, with fines for non-compliance. There is currently no fire threatening communities, however, you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.sourceTitle: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for DAMAGING WINDS
properties.name: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for DAMAGING WINDS
properties.webHeadline:
Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce damaging winds in the warning area over the next several hours. Locations which may be affected include Bright, Dargo, Falls Creek, Mt Hotham, Mt Buller and Omeo.


Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the Northern Country and North Central districts and the warning for these districts is CANCELLED.


114 km/h wind gust recorded at Mount Buller Airport at 11:20pm AEDT Thursday.
